RELATIONS AND FUNCTIONS 

There is no permanent place in the world for ugly mathematics .. . It may be very hard to define mathematical beauty but that is just as true of beauty of any kind, we may not know quite what we mean by a beautifulpoet 

1.1 Introduction 

Recall that the notion of relations and functions, domain, co-domain and range have been introduced in Class XI along with different types of specific real valued functions and their graphs. The concept of the term‘relation’ in mathematics has been drawn from the meaning of relation in English language, according to which two objects or quantities are related if there is a recognisable connection or link between the two objects or quantities. Let A be the set of students of Class XII of a school and B be the set of students of Class XI of the same school. Then some of the examples of relations from A to B are 

(i) $\{ ( a , b ) \in \mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { B } \} .$ a is brother of $b \}$ ， Lejeune Dirichlet   
(ii) $\{ ( a , b ) \in \mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { B } \colon$ a is sister of $b \}$ ， (1805-1859)   
(i) $\{ ( a , b ) \in \mathrm { A } \times \mathrm { B }$ age of $a$ is greater than age of $b \}$ ，   
(iv) $\{ ( a , b ) \in \mathrm { A } \times \mathrm { B }$ : total marks obtained by $a$ in the final examination is less than the total marks obtained by $^ { b }$ in the final examination},   
(v) $\{ ( a , b ) \in \mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { B } ; a$ lives in the same locality as $b \}$ . However, abstracting from this, we define mathematically a relation R from A to B as an arbitrary subset of $\mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { B }$ 

If $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ ,we say that $a$ is related to $^ { b }$ under the relation R and we write as $a$ R $^ { b }$ .In general, $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ ，we do not bother whether there is a recognisable connection or link between $a$ and $^ { b }$ .As seen in Class XI, functions are special kind of relations. 

In this chapter, we will study different types of relations and functions, composition of functions, invertible functions and binary operations. 

1.2 Types of Relations 

In this section, we would like to study different types of relations.We know that a relation in a set A is a subset of $\mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { A }$ .Thus, the empty set $\phi$ and $\mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { A }$ are two extreme relations.For illustration, consider a relation R in the set A $\backslash = \{ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 \}$ given by $\boldsymbol { \mathrm { R } } = \{ ( a , b )$ $a - b = 1 0 \}$ . This is the empty set, as no pair $( a , b )$ satisfies the condition $a - b = 1 0$ Similarly, $\mathrm { R } ^ { \prime } = \{ ( a , b ) : | a - b | \geq 0 \}$ is the whole set $\mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { A } .$ ,as all pairs $( a , b )$ in $\mathbf { A } \times

0 \}$ . This is the empty set, as no pair $( a , b )$ satisfies the condition $a - b = 1 0$ Similarly, $\mathrm { R } ^ { \prime } = \{ ( a , b ) : | a - b | \geq 0 \}$ is the whole set $\mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { A } .$ ,as all pairs $( a , b )$ in $\mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { A }$ satisfy $| \ a - b \ | \geq 0$ . These two extreme examples lead us to the following definitions. 

Definition 1 A relation R in a set A is called empty relation, if no element of A is related to any element ofA, i.e., $\operatorname { R } = \Phi \subset \operatorname { A } \times \operatorname { A }$ 

Definition 2 Arelation R in a set A is called universal relation, if each element of A is related to every element of A, i.e., ${ \mathrm { R } } = { \mathrm { A } } \times { \mathrm { A } }$ 

Both the empty relation and the universal relation are some times called trivial relations. ■ 

Example 1 Let A be the set of all students of a boys school. Show that the relation R in A given by $\boldsymbol { \mathrm { R } } = \{ ( a , b ) : a$ is sister of $b \}$ is the empty relation and $\ R ^ { \prime } = \{ ( a , b ) :$ the difference between heights of $a$ and $^ { b }$ is less than 3 meters} is the universal relation. 

Solution Since the school is boys school, no student of the school can be sister of any student of the school. Hence, ${ \mathrm { R } } = \phi$ ，showing that R is the empty relation. It is also obvious that the difference between heights of any two students of the school has to be less than 3 meters. This shows that $\mathrm { R ^ { \prime } } = \mathbf { A } \times \mathbf { A }$ is the universal relation. 

Remark In Class XI, we have seen two ways of representing a relation, namely raster method and set builder method. However, a relation R in the set $\{ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 \}$ defined by R $= \{ ( a , \ b ) \ : \ b \ = \ a \ + \ 1 \}$ is also expressed as $a$ R $^ { b }$ if and only if $b = a + 1$ by many authors. We may also use this notation, as and when convenient. 

If $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ , we say that $a$ is related to $^ { b }$ and we denote it as $a \mathrm { ~ R ~ } b$ 

One of the most important relation, which plays a significant role in Mathematics, is an equivalence relation. To study equivalence relation, we first consider three types of relations, namely reflexive, symmetric and transitive. 

Definition 3 A relation R in a set A is called 

(i) reflexive, if $( a , a ) \in \mathbb { R }$ ,for every $a \in \mathbf { A }$   
(ii) symmetric,if $( a _ { 1 } , a _ { 2 } ) \in \mathbb { R }$ implies that $( a _ { 2 } , a _ { 1 } ) \in \mathbb { R } _ { \mathrm { \Omega } }$ for all $a _ {

(ii) symmetric,if $( a _ { 1 } , a _ { 2 } ) \in \mathbb { R }$ implies that $( a _ { 2 } , a _ { 1 } ) \in \mathbb { R } _ { \mathrm { \Omega } }$ for all $a _ { 1 } , a _ { 2 } \in \mathbf { A }$   
(ii) transitive,if $( a _ { 1 } , a _ { 2 } ) \in \mathbb { R }$ and $( a _ { 2 } , a _ { 3 } ) \in \mathrm { R }$ implies that $( a _ { 1 } , a _ { 3 } ) \in \mathbb { R } _ { \mathtt { f } }$ for all $a _ { 1 } , a _ { 2 } ,$ $a _ { _ 3 } \in \mathrm { A }$ 

Definition 4 A relation R in a set A is said to be an equivalence relation if R is reflexive, symmetric and transitive. 

Example 2 Let Tbe the set of al triangles in a plane with R a relation in T given by $\mathbf { R } = \{ ( \mathrm { T } _ { 1 } , \mathrm { T } _ { 2 } ) : \mathrm { T } _ { 1 }$ is congruent to $\mathrm { T } _ { 2 } \}$ . Show that R is an equivalence relation. 

Solution R is reflexive, since every triangle is congruent to itself. Further, $( \mathrm { T } _ { 1 } , \mathrm { T } _ { 2 } ) \in \mathrm { R } \Rightarrow \mathrm { T } _ { 1 }$ is congruent to $\mathrm { T } _ { 2 } \Rightarrow \mathrm { T } _ { 2 }$ is congruent to $\mathrm { T } _ { 1 } \Rightarrow ( \mathrm { T } _ { 2 } , \mathrm { T } _ { 1 } ) \in \mathrm { R } .$ Hence, R is symmetric. Moreover, $( \mathrm { T } _ { 1 } , \mathrm { T } _ { 2 } )$ ， $( \Gamma _ { 2 } , \mathrm { T } _ { 3 } ) \in \mathrm { R } \Rightarrow \Gamma _ { 1 }$ iscongruent to $\mathrm { T } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { T } _ { 2 }$ is congruent to $\mathrm { T } _ { 3 } \Longrightarrow \mathrm { T } _ { 1 }$ is congruent to $\mathrm { T } _ { 3 } \Longrightarrow ( \mathrm { T } _ { 1 } , \mathrm { T } _ { 3 } ) \in \mathrm { R } .$ Therefore,R is an equivalence relation. →

Show that $\mathrm { R }$ is symmetric but neither reflexive nor transitive.

Example 4 Show that the relation R in the set $\{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ given by ${ \mathrm R } = \{ ( 1 , 1 ) , ( 2 , 2 )$ $( 3 , 3 ) , ( 1 , 2 ) , ( 2 , 3 ) \}$ is reflexive but neither symmetric nor transitive. 

Solution R is reflexive, since $( 1 , 1 ) , ( 2 , 2 )$ and (3,3) lie in R.Also, R is not symmetric, as $( 1 , 2 ) \in \mathrm { R }$ but $( 2 , 1 ) \notin \mathrm { R }$ .Similarly, R is not transitive, as $( 1 , 2 ) \in \mathrm { R }$ and $( 2 , 3 ) \in \mathrm { R }$ but $( 1 , 3 ) \not \in { \mathrm { R } }$

Example 5 Show that the relation R in the set $\mathbf { Z }$ of integers given by 

is an equivalence relation. 

Solution R is reflexive, as 2 divides $( a - a )$ for all $a \in \mathbf { Z }$ .Further, if $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ then 2 divides $a - b$ .Therefore,2 divides $b - a$ Hence, $( b , a ) \in \mathrm { R } .$ ,which shows that R is symmetric. Similarly, if $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ and $( b , c ) \in \mathrm { R } .$ then $a - b$ and $b - c$ are divisible by 2. Now, $a - c = ( a - b ) + ( b - c )$ is even (Why?). So, $( a - c )$ is divisible by 2. This shows that R is transitive. Thus,R is an equivalence relation in $\mathbf { Z }$ 

In Example 5, note that all even integers are related to zero, as $( 0 , \pm 2 )$ ， $( 0 , \pm 4 )$ etc., lie in R and no odd integer is related to O, as $( 0 , \pm 1 )$ ， $( 0 , \pm 3 )$ etc., do not lie in R. Similarly, all odd integers are related to one and no even integer is related to one. Therefore, the set E of all even integers and the set O of all odd integers are subsets of Z satisfying following conditions: 

(i)All elements of E are related to each other and all elements of O are related to each other. (ii) No element of E is related to any element of O and vice-versa. (ii) E and O are disjoint and $\mathbf { Z } = \operatorname { E } \cup \mathrm { O }$ 一 

The subset E is called the equivalence class containing zero and is denoted by [0]. Similarly, O is the equivalence class containing 1 and is denoted by[1]. Note that $[ 0 ] \neq [ 1 ] , [ 0 ] = [ 2 r ]$ and $[ 1 ] = [ 2 r + 1 ] , r \in { \bf Z }$ . Infact, what we have seen above is true for an arbitrary equivalence relation R in a set X. Given an arbitrary equivalence relation R in an arbitrary set X, R divides X into mutually disjoint subsets $\mathbf { A } _ { _ i }$ called partitions or subdivisions of X satisfying: 

(i）all elements of $\mathbf { A } _ { _ i }$ are related to each other, for all i. (ii) no element of $\mathbf { A } _ { _ i }$ is related to any element of $\mathrm { A } _ { j }$ ， $i \neq j$ (i) $\cup \mathtt { A } _ { j } = \mathtt { X }$ and $\mathbf { A } _ { i } \cap \mathbf { A } _ { j } = \boldsymbol \Phi$ $i \neq j$ 

The subsets $\mathbf { A } _ { _ i }$ are called equivalence classes. The interesting part of the situation is that we can go reverse also.For example, consider a subdivision of the set $\mathbf { Z }$ given by three mutually

The subsets $\mathbf { A } _ { _ i }$ are called equivalence classes. The interesting part of the situation is that we can go reverse also.For example, consider a subdivision of the set $\mathbf { Z }$ given by three mutually disjoint subsets $\mathbf { A } _ { 1 } , \mathbf { A } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { A } _ { 3 }$ whose union is $\mathbf { Z }$ with 

$\mathbf { A } _ { 1 } = \{ x \in \mathbf { Z } : x$ is a multiple of $3 \} = \{ . . . , - 6 , - 3 , 0 , 3 , 6 , . . . \}$ $\mathbf { A } _ { 2 } = \{ x \in \mathbf { Z } : x - 1$ is a multiple of $3 \} = \{ . . . , - 5 , - 2 , 1 , 4 , 7 , . . . \}$ $\mathbf { A } _ { 3 } = \{ x \in \mathbf { Z } : x - 2$ is a multiple of $3 \} = \{ . . . , - 4 , - 1 , 2 , 5 , 8 , . . . \}$ 

Define a relation R in $\mathbf { Z }$ given by $\mathrm { R } = \{ ( a , b ) : 3$ divides $a - b \}$ . Following the arguments similar to those used in Example 5, we can show that R is an equivalence relation. Also, $\mathbf { A } _ { 1 }$ coincides with the set of allintegers in $\mathbf { Z }$ which are related to zero, $\mathbf { A } _ { 2 }$ coincides with the set of all integers which are related to 1 and $\mathbf { A } _ { 3 }$ coincides with the set of all integers in $\mathbf { Z }$ which are related to 2. Thus, $\mathbf { A } _ { 1 } = [ 0 ] , \mathbf { A } _ { 2 } = [ 1 ]$ and ${ \bf A } _ { 3 } = [ 2 ]$ In fact, A, = [3r], $\mathbf { A } _ { 2 } ^ { } = [ 3 r ^ { + } 1 ]$ and ${ \bf A } _ { 3 } = [ 3 r + 2 ] _ { \ L }$ for all $r \in \mathbf { Z }$ 

Example 6 Let $\mathrm { R }$ be the relation defined in the set $\mathrm { A } = \{ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 \}$ by $\boldsymbol { \mathrm { R } } = \{ ( a , b ) $ : both $a$ and $^ { b }$ are either odd or even}. Show that $\mathrm { R }$ is an equivalence relation.Further, show that allthe elements of the subset $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ are related to each other and all the elements of the subset $\{ 2 , 4 , 6 \}$ are related to each other, but no element of the subset $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ is related to any element of

odd or even}. Show that $\mathrm { R }$ is an equivalence relation.Further, show that allthe elements of the subset $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ are related to each other and all the elements of the subset $\{ 2 , 4 , 6 \}$ are related to each other, but no element of the subset $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ is related to any element of the subset {2, 4, 6}. 

Solution Given any element $a$ in A, both $a$ and $a$ must be either odd or even, so that $( a , a ) \in \mathbb { R }$ Further, $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R } \Rightarrow$ both $a$ and $^ { b }$ must be either odd or even $\Rightarrow ( b , a ) \in \mathrm { R }$ Similarly, $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ and $( b , c ) \in \mathrm { R } \Rightarrow$ all elements $a , b , c ,$ must be either even or odd simultaneously $\Rightarrow ( a , c ) \in \operatorname { R } .$ Hence,R is an equivalence relation. Further, all the elements of $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ are related to each other, as all the elements of this subset are odd. Similarly,allthe elements of the subset $\{ 2 , 4 , 6 \}$ are related to each other, as all of them are even. Also, no element of the subset $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ can be related to any element of $\{ 2 , 4 , 6 \}$ , as elements of $\{ 1 , 3 , 5 , 7 \}$ are odd, while elements of {2, 4, 6} are even.

1.3 Types of Functions 

The notion of a function along with some special functions like identity function, constant function, polynomial function, rational function, modulus function, signum function etc. along with their graphs have been given in Class XI. 一 

Addition, subtraction, multiplication and division of two functions have also been studied. As the concept of function is of paramount importance in mathematics and among other disciplines as well we would like to extend our study about function from where we finished earlier. In this section, we would like to study different types of functions. 

Consider the functions $f _ { 1 } , f _ { 2 } , f _ { 3 }$ and $f _ { 4 }$ given by the following diagrams. 

In Fig 1.2, we observe that the images of distinct elements of $\mathrm { X } _ { \mathrm { 1 } }$ under the function $f _ { 1 }$ are distinct, but the image of two distinct elements 1 and 2 of $\mathrm { X } _ { \mathrm { 1 } }$ under $f _ { 2 }$ is same, namely $b$ .Further, there are some elements like $e$ and $f$ in $\mathrm { X } _ { _ 2 }$ which are not images of any element of $\mathrm { X } _ { \mathrm { 1 } }$ under $f _ { \scriptscriptstyle 1 }$ , while all elements of $\mathrm { X } _ { _ 3 }$ are images of some elements of $\mathrm { X } _ { \mathrm { 1 } }$ under $f _ { 3 }$ . The above observations lead to the following definitions: 

Definition 5 A function f: $\Chi \to \Upsilon$ is defined to be one-one (or injective),if the images of distinct elements of $\mathrm { X }$ under $f$ are distinct, i.e., for every $x _ { 1 } , x _ { 2 } \in \mathrm { X } , f ( x _ { 1 } ) = f ( x _ { 2 } )$ implies $x _ { 1 } = x _ { 2 }$ . Otherwise, $f$ is called many-one. 

The function $f _ { 1 }$ and $f _ { 4

$ under $f$ are distinct, i.e., for every $x _ { 1 } , x _ { 2 } \in \mathrm { X } , f ( x _ { 1 } ) = f ( x _ { 2 } )$ implies $x _ { 1 } = x _ { 2 }$ . Otherwise, $f$ is called many-one. 

The function $f _ { 1 }$ and $f _ { 4 }$ in Fig 1.2 (i) and (iv)are one-one and the function $f _ { 2 }$ and $f _ { 3 }$ in Fig 1.2 (ii) and (iii) are many-one. 

Definition 6 A function f $\colon \mathrm { X }  \mathrm { Y }$ is said to be onto (or surjective), if every element of Y is the image of some element of $\mathrm { X }$ under $f ,$ i.e., for every $y \in \mathrm { Y } ,$ there exists an element $x$ in $\mathrm { X }$ such that $f ( x ) = y$ 

The function $f _ { 3 }$ and $f _ { 4 }$ in Fig 1.2 (i), (iv) are onto and the function $f _ { 1 }$ in Fig 1.2 (i) is not onto as elements $e , f$ in $\mathrm { X } _ { _ 2 }$ are not the image of any element in $\mathrm { X } _ { _ 1 }$ under $f _ { 1 }$

Therefore, both $x _ { 1 }$ and $x _ { _ 2 }$ must be either odd or even. Suppose both $x _ { 1 }$ and $x _ { 2 }$ are odd. Example 13 Show that an onto function $f \colon \{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}  \{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ is always one-one. 

Solution Suppose $f$ is not one-one. Then there exists two elements, say 1 and 2 in the domain whose image in the co-domain is same.Also, the image of 3 under $f$ can be only one element. Therefore, the range set can have at the most two elements of the co-domain {1,2,3},showing that $f$ is not onto,a contradiction. Hence,fmust be one-one. 

Example 14 Show that a one-one function $f \colon \{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}  \{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ must be onto. 

Solution Since $f$ is one-one, three elements of $\{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ must be taken to 3 different elements of the co-domain $\{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ under $f .$ Hence, $f$ has to be onto. 

Remark The results mentioned in Examples 13 and 14 are also true for an arbitrary finite set X, i.e., a one-one function $f \colon X \to X$ is necessarily onto and an onto map $f \colon X \to X$ is necessarily one-one, for every finite set X. In contrast to this, Examples 8 and 1O show that for an infinite set, this may not be true.In fact, this is a characteristic difference between a finite and an infinite set.

Definition 9 A function $f \colon X \to \mathrm { Y }$ is defined to be invertible, if there exists a function $g : \mathrm { Y } \to \mathrm { X }$ such that $g o f { = } \mathrm { I _ { x } } \mathrm { a n d } f o g { = } \mathrm { I _ { y } } .$ The function $g$ is called the inverse off and is denoted by $f ^ { - 1 }$

Solution Since $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ and $\mathrm { R } _ { 2 }$ are equivalence relations, $( a , a ) \in \mathrm { R } _ { 1 } { : }$ and $( a , a ) \in \mathrm { R } _ { 2 } \ \forall a \in \mathrm { A }$ This implies that $( a , a ) \in \mathrm { R } _ { 1 } \cap \mathrm { R } _ { 2 } , \forall a .$ ，showing $\mathsf { R } _ { 1 } \cap \mathsf { R } _ { 2 }$ is reflexive. Example 22 Find the number of all one-one functions from set $A = \{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ to itself.

Example 23 Let $A = \{ 1 , 2 , 3 \} .$ Then show that the number ofrelations containing $( 1 , 2 )$ and (2, 3) which are reflexive and transitive but not symmetric is three. 

Solution The smallest relation $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ containing $( 1 , 2 )$ and $( 2 , 3 )$ which is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric is $\{ ( 1 , 1 ) , ( 2 , 2 ) , ( 3 , 3 ) , ( 1 , 2 ) , ( 2 , 3 ) , ( 1 , 3 ) \}$ .Now, if we add the pair (2, 1) to $\mathrm { R } _ { _ 1 }$ to get $\mathrm { R } _ { 2 }$ , then the relation $\mathrm { R }

$\{ ( 1 , 1 ) , ( 2 , 2 ) , ( 3 , 3 ) , ( 1 , 2 ) , ( 2 , 3 ) , ( 1 , 3 ) \}$ .Now, if we add the pair (2, 1) to $\mathrm { R } _ { _ 1 }$ to get $\mathrm { R } _ { 2 }$ , then the relation $\mathrm { R } _ { 2 }$ will be reflexive, transitive but not symmetric. Similarly, we can obtain $\mathrm { R } _ { _ 3 }$ by adding $( 3 , 2 )$ to $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ to get the desired relation. However, we can not add two pairs (2,1), (3,2) or single pair $( 3 , 1 )$ to $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ at a time, as by doing so, we will be forced to add the remaining pair in order to maintain transitivity and in the process, the relation willbecome symmetric also which is not required. Thus, the total number of desired relations is three. 

Example 24 Show that the number ofequivalence relation in the set $\{ 1 , 2 , 3 \}$ containing (1,2) and (2, 1) is two. 

Solution The smallest equivalence relation $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ containing (1,2) and (2,1) is $\{ ( 1 , 1 )$ (2, 2), (3,3), (1,2), (2,1)}. Now we are left with only 4 pairs namely (2,3), (3,2), (1, 3) and (3,1). If we add any one, say (2, 3) to $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ , then for symmetry we must add (3,2) also and now for transitivity we are forced to add $( 1 , 3 )$ and (3,1). Thus,the only equivalence relation bigger than $\mathrm { R } _ { 1 }$ is the universal relation. This shows that the total number of equivalence relations containing $( 1 , 2 )$ and $( 2 , 1 )$ is two.

Summary 

In this chapter, we studied different types of relations and equivalence relation, composition of functions, invertible functions and binary operations. The main features of this chapter are as follows: 

$\spadesuit$ Empty relation is the relation R in X given by ${ \mathrm { R } } = \phi \subset \mathrm { X } \times \mathrm { X }$   
$\spadesuit$ Universal relation is the relation R in X given by $\mathrm { R } = \mathrm { X } \times \mathrm { X } .$   
$\diamond$ Reflexive relation R in X is a relation with $( a , a ) \in \mathbb { R } \ \forall a \in \mathrm { X } .$   
$\spadesuit$ Symmetric relation R in $\mathrm { X }$ is a relation satisfying $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ implies $( b , a ) \in \mathrm { R } .$   
$\diamond$ Transitive relation R in $\mathrm { X }$ is a relation satisfying $( a , b ) \in \mathbb { R }$ and $( b , c ) \in \mathrm { R }$ implies that $( a , c ) \in \mathrm { R }$   
$\diamond$ Equivalence relation $\mathrm { R }$ in $\mathrm { X }$ is a relation which is reflexive, symmetric and transitive.   
$\spadesuit$ Equivalence class $[ a ]$ containing $a \in \mathrm { X }$ for an equivalence relation R in $\mathrm { X }$ is the subset of $\mathrm { X }$ containing all elements $^ { b }$ related to $a$   
$\diamond$ A function $f \colon X \to \mathrm { Y }$ is one-one (or injective) if $f ( x _ { 1 } ) = f ( x _ { 2 } ) \Rightarrow x _ { 1 } = x _ { 2 } \forall x _ { 1 } , x _ { 2 } \in \mathrm { X } .$   
$\diamond$ A function f : $\Chi \to \ Y$ is onto (or surjective) if given any $y \in \mathrm { Y } , \exists x \in \mathrm { X }$ such that $

chunk-71176e4ec689ba3bea6427696769add3.content:
} ) = f ( x _ { 2 } ) \Rightarrow x _ { 1 } = x _ { 2 } \forall x _ { 1 } , x _ { 2 } \in \mathrm { X } .$   
$\diamond$ A function f : $\Chi \to \ Y$ is onto (or surjective) if given any $y \in \mathrm { Y } , \exists x \in \mathrm { X }$ such that $f ( x ) = y$   
$\spadesuit$ A function, $f \colon \mathrm { X }  \mathrm { Y }$ is one-one and onto (or bijective),iffis both one-one and onto.   
$\diamond$ Given a finite set X, a functionf : $\Chi \to \Chi$ is one-one (respectively onto) if and only iffis onto (respectively one-one). This is the characteristic property of a finite set. This is not true for infinite set 

Historical Note 

The concept of function has evolved over a long period of time starting from R. Descartes (1596-1650), who used the word ‘function’ in his manuscript "Geometrie” in 1637 to mean some positive integral power $x ^ { n }$ of a variable $x$ while studying geometrical curves like hyperbola, parabola and ellpse. James Gregory (i636-1675) in his work “ Vera Circuli et Hyperbolae Quadratura” (1667) considered function as a quantity obtained from other quantities by successive use of algebraic operations or by any other operations. Later G. W. Leibnitz (1646-1716) in his manuscript “Methodus tangentium inversa, seu de functionibus” writen in 1673 used the word ‘function’to mean a quantity varying from point to point on a curve such as the coordinates of a point on the curve, the slope of the curve, the tangent and the normal to the curve at a point. However, in his manuscript “Historia’ (1714), Leibnitz used the word ‘function’ to mean quantities that depend on a variable. He was the first to use the phrase ‘function of $x '$ . John Bernoulli (1667-1748) used the notation $\phi x$ for the first time in 1718 to indicate a function of $x$ But the general adoption of symbols like f, F, $\boldsymbol { \Phi }$ ， $\boldsymbol { \Psi }$ ...to represent functions was made by Leonhard Euler(1707-1783) in 1734 in the first part of his manuscript “Analysis Infinitorium". Later on, Joeph Louis Lagrange (1736-1813) published his manuscripts “Theorie des functions analytiques" in 1793, where he discussed about analytic function and used the notion $f ( x ) , \operatorname { F } ( x ) .$ $\phi ( x )$ 'etc. for different function of $x$ . Subsequently, Lejeunne Dirichlet (1805-1859) gave the definition of function which was being used til the set theoretic definition of function presently used, was given after set theory was developed by Georg Cantor (1845-1918). The set theoretic definition of function known to us presently is simply an abstraction of the definition given by Dirichlet in a rigorous manner.

chunk-1cf878390efdd6def2787d9e1a55e86c.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
{ \mathrm { R } } = \{ ( a , b ) : 2 { \mathrm { d i v i d e s } } a - b \}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation defines a relation R on a set A by specifying the set of ordered pairs (a, b) such that the integer 2 divides the difference a - b. Mathematically, this means (a, b) belongs to R if and only if a - b is an even integer, i.e., there exists an integer k such that a - b = 2k. Here, '2 divides a - b' is a divisibility condition, a fundamental concept in number theory. The variables a and b represent elements of the set A, which is typically a subset of integers or any set where subtraction and divisibility are defined. The relation R is thus the set of all pairs whose difference is even. This relation is an example of an equivalence relation because it satisfies reflexivity (a - a = 0, divisible by 2), symmetry (if 2 divides a - b, then 2 divides b - a), and transitivity (if 2 divides a - b and 2 divides b - c, then 2 divides a - c). In the broader context of relations, this equation illustrates how algebraic properties (divisibility) can define equivalence classes, partitioning the set A into subsets of elements congruent modulo 2. This concept is foundational in modular arithmetic and has applications in abstract algebra, coding theory, and computer science. The relation groups elements into two equivalence classes: those congruent to 0 mod 2 (even numbers) and those congruent to 1 mod 2 (odd numbers). This example concretely demonstrates the abstract definitions of relations, equivalence relations, and their properties discussed in the surrounding content.

chunk-d86683b80969f3ebd8fb391d36f3afce.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
f ( x ) = \begin{array} { l } { x + 1 , { \mathrm { i f ~ } } x { \mathrm { ~ i s ~ o d d , } } } \\ { x - 1 , { \mathrm { i f ~ } } x { \mathrm { ~ i s ~ e v e n } } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation defines a piecewise function f: \mathbf{N} \to \mathbf{N} where the output depends on the parity of the input x. Specifically, for odd x, f(x) = x + 1, and for even x, f(x) = x - 1. This function is a bijection (one-one and onto) on the natural numbers, as it pairs each odd number with the next even number and each even number with the preceding odd number, establishing a perfect two-way correspondence between odd and even natural numbers. The variables are: x, an element of the domain \mathbf{N} (natural numbers), and f(x), the image in the codomain \mathbf{N}. The operations used are addition and subtraction by 1, conditioned on parity (odd/even) of x. The function exploits the parity property to create an involution-like mapping that is its own inverse. In the broader context of the text, this function serves as an example illustrating bijections between infinite sets, highlighting that infinite sets can have non-trivial bijections that differ from identity mappings. It contrasts with earlier examples where functions were one-one but not onto or vice versa, emphasizing the subtlety of bijections in infinite domains. The function's theoretical significance lies in demonstrating the concept of bijections and the equivalence in cardinality between the set of odd and even natural numbers, a foundational idea in set theory and cardinality of infinite sets. Practically, such functions are used in combinatorics, number theory, and computer science for indexing, pairing functions, and constructing bijections between countably infinite sets. This example also supports the broader discussion on the properties of functions (one-one, onto, bijective) and their implications in finite versus infinite sets, reinforcing the characteristic differences in function behavior across these domains.

chunk-0c1d9fa30b62b8eb133bdae8ac387f5f.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
{ \begin{array} { r l } & { f \colon \mathbf { N } \to \mathbf { N } { \mathrm { ~ g i v e n ~ b y ~ } } f ( x ) = x ^ { 2 } } \\ & { f \colon \mathbf { Z } \to \mathbf { Z } { \mathrm { ~ g i v e n ~ b y ~ } } f ( x ) = x ^ { 2 } } \\ & { f \colon \mathbf { R } \to \mathbf { R } { \mathrm { ~ g i v e n ~ b y ~ } } f ( x ) = x ^ { 2 } } \\ & { f \colon \mathbf { N } \to \mathbf { N } { \mathrm { ~ g i v e n ~ b y ~ } } f ( x ) = x ^ { 3 } } \\ & { f \colon \mathbf { Z } \to \mathbf { Z } { \mathrm { ~ g i v e n ~ b y ~ } } f ( x ) = x ^ { 3 } } \end{array} }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given set of equations defines functions f with various domains and codomains, mapping elements x to their powers, specifically squares (x^2) and cubes (x^3). The functions are defined as follows: f: N → N with f(x) = x^2, f: Z → Z with f(x) = x^2, f: R → R with f(x) = x^2, f: N → N with f(x) = x^3, and f: Z → Z with f(x) = x^3. Here, N denotes the set of natural numbers, Z the set of integers, and R the set of real numbers. The mathematical operations involved are exponentiation, a unary operation raising x to the power 2 or 3. These functions are polynomial mappings of degree 2 or 3. The context is the study of injectivity (one-one) and surjectivity (onto) of functions between sets, particularly infinite sets such as N, Z, and R. The square function f(x) = x^2 is neither injective nor surjective over Z and R because it maps both positive and negative inputs to the same output (e.g., f(1) = f(-1) = 1), and negative numbers in the codomain have no preimage. Over N, f(x) = x^2 is injective but not surjective since not all natural numbers are perfect squares. The cube function f(x) = x^3 is injective and surjective over Z and R because it is strictly monotonic and covers all integers or real numbers respectively. Over N, f(x) = x^3 is injective but not surjective since not all natural numbers are perfect cubes. These functions illustrate fundamental concepts in function theory, such as the impact of domain and codomain choice on injectivity and surjectivity, and highlight differences between finite and infinite sets. They also relate to polynomial function properties, monotonicity, and the structure of number sets. Practically, these functions model growth processes, transformations in algebra, and are foundational in analysis and number theory. Within the broader discussion, these examples serve to contrast the behavior of functions on finite versus infinite sets and to demonstrate criteria for one-one and onto mappings, reinforcing the theoretical framework of function properties.

chunk-4cd21694a40bd99fd8e1c50fe4056e4e.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
f ( x ) = \left\{ { \begin{array} { l } { 1 , { \mathrm { i f ~ } } x > 0 } \\ { 0 , { \mathrm { i f ~ } } x = 0 } \\ { 1 , { \mathrm { i f ~ } } x < 0 } \end{array} } \right.
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given piecewise function f(x) is defined on the real numbers with three cases: f(x) = 1 if x > 0, f(x) = 0 if x = 0, and f(x) = 1 if x < 0. This function is a variant of the Signum function, which typically distinguishes the sign of a real number by mapping positive inputs to 1, zero to 0, and negative inputs to -1. Here, however, both positive and negative inputs map to 1, while zero maps to 0. The variable x represents a real number, and the function partitions the domain into three mutually exclusive subsets based on the sign of x. The operations used are conditional definitions and constant mappings. In the context of the surrounding material, which discusses injectivity (one-one), surjectivity (onto), and bijectivity of functions, this function serves as an example to analyze these properties. Specifically, since f(x) maps all nonzero real numbers to 1, it is not injective (many-to-one) because multiple inputs share the same output. It is also not surjective onto the codomain R if the codomain includes values other than 0 and 1, as only these two values appear in the range. The function's theoretical significance lies in illustrating functions that are neither injective nor surjective, highlighting the importance of these properties in function theory. It relates to other examples in the text that examine the injectivity and surjectivity of various functions, such as the Greatest Integer function and the Modulus function. Practically, such a function could model a binary classification where all nonzero inputs are treated identically, except zero, which is distinguished. This function exemplifies how function properties differ when the codomain and domain are structured or restricted, contributing to the broader discussion on function mappings, their invertibility, and characteristics in finite versus infinite sets.

chunk-42e6c5a22a42568f670dce9e3f18547f.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
g o f ( x ) = g ( f ( x ) ) , ~ \forall ~ x \in \operatorname { A } .
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $g \circ f (x) = g(f(x))$, for all $x \in A$, defines the composition of two functions $f$ and $g$. Here, $f: A \to B$ and $g: B \to C$ are functions between sets $A$, $B$, and $C$. The composition $g \circ f$ is a function from $A$ to $C$ obtained by first applying $f$ to an element $x$ in $A$ to get $f(x) \in B$, and then applying $g$ to $f(x)$ to get $g(f(x)) \in C$. This operation is fundamental in function theory, illustrating how functions can be combined to form new functions. The variables are: $x$, an element of the domain set $A$; $f$, a function mapping $A$ to $B$; and $g$, a function mapping $B$ to $C$. The mathematical operation used is function composition, which is associative but generally not commutative. The context involves studying properties of functions such as one-to-one (injectivity), onto (surjectivity), invertibility, and the behavior of composed functions. The equation is significant in understanding how complex mappings can be constructed from simpler ones and is essential in defining invertible functions, where the existence of an inverse function $g$ satisfying $g \circ f = I_A$ and $f \circ g = I_B$ (identity functions) characterizes bijections. This concept is widely applicable in algebra, analysis, and applied mathematics, including solving equations, transformations, and functional programming. Within the broader framework, this equation underpins the discussion on invertible functions and their inverses, highlighting the importance of composition in verifying invertibility and constructing inverse functions.

chunk-b812020c1b74c5615a21a93c1c4fd086.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
g ( y ) = { \frac { ( y - 3 ) } { 4 } } . \operatorname { N o w } , g o f ( x ) = g \left( f ( x ) \right) = g ( 4 x + 3 ) = { \frac { ( 4 x + 3 - 3 ) } { 4 } } = x
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation defines the function g as the inverse of the function f, where f is given by f(x) = 4x + 3 with domain and codomain subsets of the natural numbers. The function g is explicitly constructed as g(y) = (y - 3) / 4, effectively reversing the operation of f. The composition g o f (x) = g(f(x)) simplifies to x, demonstrating that g is a left inverse of f. Here, x is a natural number in the domain of f, and y is in the codomain of f, specifically the set Y = {y in N : y = 4x + 3 for some x in N}. The operations involved include linear transformation, subtraction, division, and function composition. This equation is situated in the context of invertible functions, illustrating the concept that a function is invertible if there exists a function g such that g o f = I_N, the identity on the domain. The theoretical significance lies in confirming that f is bijective (one-to-one and onto) on its domain and codomain, thus invertible. This example concretely demonstrates the process of finding an inverse function algebraically and verifying the inverse relationship through composition. It relates to broader discussions on function invertibility, composition, and identity functions, foundational in algebra and analysis. Practical applications include solving linear equations, coding theory, and any domain requiring reversible transformations. The equation exemplifies the fundamental property that invertible functions have unique inverses that undo their action, a key concept in many mathematical frameworks.

INVERSE TRIGONOMETRIC FUNCTIONS 

Mathematics, in general, is fundamentally the science of self-evident things. - FELIX KLEIN 

2.1 Introduction 

In Chapter 1, we have studied that the inverse of a function $f ,$ denoted by $f ^ { - 1 }$ ,exists iffis one-one and onto. There are many functions which are not one-one, onto or both and hence we can not talk of their inverses.In Class XI, we studied that trigonometric functions are not one-one and onto over their natural domains and ranges and hence their inverses do not exist.In this chapter, we shall study about the restrictions on domains and ranges of trigonometric functions which ensure the existence of their inverses and observe their behaviour through graphical representations. Besides, some elementary properties will also be discussed. 

The inverse trigonometric functions play an important role in calculus for they serve to define many integrals. 

The concepts ofinverse trigonometric functions is also used in science and engineering.

Like sine function, the cosine function is a function whose domain is the set of äall real numbers and range is the set $[ - 1 , 1 ]$ . Actually, cosine function restricted to any of the intervals $[ - \pi , 0 ]$ ， $[ 0 , \pi ] , [ \pi , 2 \pi ]$ etc., is bijective with range as $[ - 1 , \ 1 ]$ . Thus, $\cos ^ { - 1 }$ is a function whose domain is $[ - 1 , \ 1 ]$ and range could be any of the intervals $[ - \pi , \ 0 ] , \ [ 0 , \ \pi ] , \ [ \pi , \ 2 \pi ]$ etc. Corresponding to each such interval, we get a branch of the function $\cos ^ { - 1 }$ . It may be mentioned here that these results are valid within the principal value branches of the corresponding inverse trigonometric functions and wherever they are defined. Historical Note 

The study of trigonometry was first started in India. The ancient Indian Mathematicians, Aryabhata (476A.D.), Brahmagupta (598 A.D.), Bhaskara I (600 A.D.) and Bhaskara II(1i14 A.D.) got important results of trigonometry. All this knowledge went from India to Arabia and then from there to Europe. The Greeks had also started the study of trigonometry but their approach was so clumsy that when the Indian approach became known, it was immediately adopted throughout the world. 

In India, the predecessor of the modern trigonometric functions, known as the sine of an angle, and the introduction of the sine function represents one of the main contribution of the siddhantas (Sanskrit astronomical works) to mathematics. 

Bhaskara I(about 6Oo A.D.) gave formulae to find the values of sine functions for angles more than $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ . A sixteenth century Malayalam work Yuktibhasa contains a proof for the expansion of sin $\left( \mathsf { A } + \mathsf { B } \right)$ . Exact expression for sines or cosines of $1 8 ^ { \circ }$ ， $3 6 ^ { \circ }$ ， $5 4 ^ { \circ }$ $7 2 ^ { \circ }$ , etc., were given by Bhaskara II. 

The symbols $\sin ^ { - 1 } x$ ， $\cos ^ { - 1 } { x } ,$ etc., for arc $\sin x .$ arc $\cos x ,$ etc., were suggested by the astronomer Sir John F.W. Hersehel (1813) The name of Thales (about $6 0 0 \mathrm { B . C . }$ ) is invariably associated with height and distance problems. He is credited with the determination of the height of a great pyramid in Egypt by measuring shadows of the pyramid and an auxiliary staff (or gnomon) of known height, and comparing the ratios: 

Thales is also said to have calculated the distance of a ship at sea through the proportionality of sides of similar triangles.Problems on height and distance using the similarity property are also found in ancient Indian works.

chunk-60c7ec8005d9e472efae5a1e90c3bba2.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\left( f ^ { - 1 } \circ f \right) ( x ) = f ^ { - 1 } \left( f ( x ) \right) = f ^ { - 1 } ( y ) = x
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( (f^{-1} \circ f)(x) = f^{-1}(f(x)) = f^{-1}(y) = x \) expresses the fundamental property of inverse functions in mathematics. Here, \(f\) is a bijective function from a set \(X\) to a set \(Y\), and \(f^{-1}\) is its inverse function from \(Y\) back to \(X\). The variable \(x \in X\) is an element of the domain of \(f\), and \(y = f(x) \in Y\) is the corresponding element in the codomain. The composition \(f^{-1} \circ f\) means applying \(f\) first and then \(f^{-1}\), which returns the original input \(x\). This identity confirms that \(f^{-1}\) reverses the effect of \(f\), a defining characteristic of inverse functions. The equation involves function composition and the concept of bijection (one-to-one and onto mappings). In the context of inverse trigonometric functions, this property underpins the definition of inverse sine, cosine, and other inverse trig functions, ensuring that applying the inverse function to the output of the original function recovers the input within the restricted domain where the function is bijective. This is crucial for defining principal value branches of inverse trig functions, which are used extensively in calculus, integration, and solving trigonometric equations. The equation relates to the broader framework of function invertibility, domain and range restrictions, and the graphical interpretation of inverse functions as reflections about the line \(y = x\). Practically, it enables the evaluation of inverse trigonometric functions and their use in engineering, physics, and other applied sciences where angles and periodic phenomena are analyzed.

chunk-5b862741472877124bf70e8f2964c726.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
( f \circ f ^ { - 1 } ) \ ( y ) = f ( f ^ { - 1 } ( y ) ) \ = f ( x ) = y
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation (f \circ f^{-1})(y) = f(f^{-1}(y)) = f(x) = y expresses the fundamental property of inverse functions in the context of function composition. Here, f is a bijective function from a set X to a set Y, and f^{-1} is its inverse function from Y back to X. The variable y \in Y is an element in the codomain of f, and x \in X is the unique element such that f(x) = y. The composition f \circ f^{-1} means applying f^{-1} first to y, then applying f to the result, which returns y itself, demonstrating that f and f^{-1} are mutual inverses. This property is central to the theory of inverse functions and is crucial in defining inverse trigonometric functions, where the original trigonometric function is restricted to a domain ensuring bijectivity. The equation underpins the principal value branches of inverse trigonometric functions, such as arcsine and arccosine, by guaranteeing that applying the function and its inverse in succession yields the identity on the appropriate domain. It also relates to the graphical interpretation where the graph of an inverse function is the reflection of the original function's graph about the line y = x. This concept is foundational in calculus, analysis, and applications in science and engineering, where inverse trigonometric functions are used to solve equations, evaluate integrals, and model periodic phenomena.

chunk-c3b1d555efc0caad5d033cc1feabab35.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\cos ^ { - 1 } : [ - 1 , 1 ]  [ 0 , \pi ] .
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \cos^{-1} : [-1, 1] \to [0, \pi] \) defines the principal branch of the inverse cosine function, also known as the arccosine function. Mathematically, it represents a function mapping from the closed interval \([-1, 1]\), which is the range of the cosine function restricted to \([0, \pi]\), back to the interval \([0, \pi]\), the principal domain of the inverse function. Here, the variable \(x\) in the domain \([-1, 1]\) corresponds to the cosine value, and the output \(y = \cos^{-1} x\) is the angle in radians whose cosine is \(x\). The function is bijective on this domain and range, ensuring the existence of a well-defined inverse. The operation involved is the inverse trigonometric function, which is the inverse of the cosine function restricted to a domain where it is one-to-one and onto. This restriction is necessary because the cosine function is periodic and not injective over all real numbers. The principal value branch \([0, \pi]\) is chosen to provide a unique output for each input in \([-1, 1]\). This equation is fundamental in trigonometry, calculus, and analysis, especially in solving equations involving cosine and in defining angles from cosine values. It relates closely to the concept of function inverses, domain and range restrictions, and the geometric interpretation of inverse functions as reflections about the line \(y = x\). Practical applications include signal processing, physics (wave and oscillation analysis), engineering, and computer graphics where angle determination from cosine values is required. Within the broader discussion, this equation exemplifies the method of defining inverse trigonometric functions by restricting the domain of the original function to ensure invertibility and highlights the principal value branch concept critical for consistent function definition.

chunk-0bfd8364ceeb2d1db4a985e2494b8ed2.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\mathrm { c o s e c } ^ { - 1 } : \mathbf { R } - ( - 1 , 1 )  [ \frac { - \pi } { 2 } , \frac { \pi } { 2 } ] - \{ 0 \}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation describes the inverse cosecant function, denoted as \( \csc^{-1} \), specifying its domain and principal value range. Mathematically, \( \csc^{-1} : \mathbf{R} \setminus (-1,1) \to \left[ -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right] \setminus \{0\} \) means that the inverse cosecant function is defined for all real numbers except those strictly between -1 and 1, reflecting the fact that the cosecant function \( \csc x = \frac{1}{\sin x} \) only attains values outside this interval. The range excludes zero to maintain the function's bijectivity and avoid the singularity at \( x=0 \) where \( \csc x \) is undefined. The interval \( \left[ -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right] \setminus \{0\} \) is chosen as the principal branch, ensuring the inverse function is single-valued and continuous on this domain. This inverse function maps values back to angles whose cosecant equals the input, consistent with the restricted domain of the original cosecant function to guarantee invertibility. The equation involves set subtraction and interval notation to precisely define domain and range, reflecting the function's multivalued nature and the necessity of branch selection. In the broader context of inverse trigonometric functions, this equation parallels the definitions of other inverse functions like \( \cos^{-1} \), \( \sec^{-1} \), and \( \tan^{-1} \), each with carefully chosen principal branches to ensure well-defined inverses. The physical or theoretical significance lies in solving trigonometric equations and modeling periodic phenomena where inverse trigonometric functions arise. Practical applications include signal processing, geometry, and engineering problems involving angles and periodicity. This equation situates the inverse cosecant function within the framework of inverse trigonometric functions, emphasizing domain restrictions and principal value branches essential for mathematical rigor and functional analysis.
chunk-0bfd8364ceeb2d1db4a985e2494b8ed2.modal_entity_name: Inverse Cosecant Function Definition and Principal Branch (equation)

chunk-2918dcc053395e90b48e33306386c5fb.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\sec ^ { - 1 } : \mathbf { R } - ( - 1 , 1 ) \to [ 0 , \pi ] - \{ { \frac { \pi } { 2 } } \}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation defines the inverse secant function, denoted as \( \sec^{-1} \), as a mapping from the domain \( \mathbf{R} - (-1,1) \) to the range \( [0, \pi] - \{ \frac{\pi}{2} \} \). Mathematically, this means that \( \sec^{-1}(x) \) is defined for all real numbers \( x \) except those strictly between -1 and 1, reflecting the fact that the secant function \( \sec x = \frac{1}{\cos x} \) does not take values in the open interval \((-1,1)\). The range excludes \( \frac{\pi}{2} \) because \( \sec x \) is not defined at \( x = \frac{\pi}{2} \) where \( \cos x = 0 \). The interval \( [0, \pi] - \{ \frac{\pi}{2} \} \) is chosen as the principal branch of the inverse secant function, ensuring the function is bijective (one-to-one and onto) on this domain and range. This restriction is necessary because the secant function is periodic and not one-to-one over its entire domain. The inverse secant function thus returns the unique angle in this principal interval whose secant is \( x \). This concept is closely related to the inverse trigonometric functions and their principal branches, which are fundamental in solving trigonometric equations and in calculus. The equation fits into the broader discussion of defining inverse trigonometric functions by restricting domains to obtain bijections, enabling well-defined inverses. Practical applications include solving problems in geometry, physics, and engineering where angles must be recovered from secant values, such as in wave analysis, signal processing, and solving integrals involving secant functions.
chunk-2918dcc053395e90b48e33306386c5fb.modal_entity_name: Inverse Secant Function Principal Branch Definition (equation)

chunk-db4315552f54af37c2f44a5af5f9bca5.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\tan ^ { - 1 } : \mathbf { R }  ( { \frac { - \pi } { 2 } } , { \frac { \pi } { 2 } } )
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \tan^{-1} : \mathbf{R} \to \left( -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right) \) defines the inverse tangent function, also known as arctangent, as a mapping from the set of all real numbers \( \mathbf{R} \) to the open interval \( \left( -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right) \). This function is the principal value branch of the inverse tangent, which is the unique inverse of the tangent function restricted to the domain \( \left( -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right) \) where tangent is bijective. The variable \( x \in \mathbf{R} \) represents the input real number, and the output \( y = \tan^{-1}(x) \) is the angle in radians whose tangent is \( x \). The mathematical operation involved is the inverse of the tangent function, which is a transcendental function related to the ratio of sine and cosine. The principal value range ensures the function is well-defined and single-valued, avoiding the periodicity and discontinuities of tangent. This equation is fundamental in trigonometry, calculus, and complex analysis, providing a way to retrieve angles from tangent values. It relates to other inverse trigonometric functions like \( \cot^{-1} \), \( \sec^{-1} \), and their principal branches, as discussed in the surrounding context. Practical applications include solving trigonometric equations, integration techniques, and modeling periodic phenomena. Within the broader framework, this equation establishes the foundational domain and range for the inverse tangent function, enabling consistent graphing, analysis, and use in mathematical and physical problems.

Equation: $$
\operatorname { t } y = { \frac { - 1 } { \sqrt { 3 } } } = - \cot \left( { \frac { \pi } { 3 } } \right) = \cot \left( \pi - { \frac { \pi } { 3 } } \right) = \cot \left( { \frac { 2 \pi } { 3 } } \right)
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation expresses the value of the variable ty as a specific trigonometric value involving the cotangent function. It states that ty equals -1 divided by the square root of 3, which is equivalent to the negative cotangent of π/3. Using the cotangent's periodic and symmetry properties, this negative value is rewritten as the cotangent of π minus π/3, simplifying to cot(2π/3). Here, ty represents a real number corresponding to a trigonometric ratio. The equation uses the cotangent function, its negative, and the angle subtraction identity cot(π - θ) = -cot(θ). This is situated in the context of inverse trigonometric functions, specifically the principal value branch of cotangent inverse, which has a range (0, π). The equation demonstrates how to find the principal value of cot⁻¹(ty) by identifying the angle in the principal range whose cotangent equals ty. This relates to the broader discussion on inverse trigonometric functions, their principal branches, and the importance of correctly interpreting inverse functions versus reciprocal functions. The physical or theoretical significance lies in solving trigonometric equations and understanding inverse function values within their principal branches. It connects to other inverse trigonometric concepts by illustrating the use of angle transformations to find principal values. Practical applications include solving trigonometric equations in geometry, physics, and engineering where angle determination from ratios is required. Overall, the equation exemplifies the method of expressing a negative cotangent value as a cotangent of an angle within the principal range, reinforcing the understanding of inverse cotangent function values and their principal branches.

chunk-40dd4dc1bc0be07f5c07f72a3a6fd922.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\sin \left( \sin ^ { - 1 } x \right) = x , x \in \ [ - 1 , 1 ] { \mathrm { ~ a n d ~ } } \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( \sin x \right) = x , x \in \left[ { \frac { - \pi } { 2 } } , { \frac { \pi } { 2 } } \right]
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation presents two fundamental identities involving the sine function and its inverse, the arcsine function. The first identity, \( \sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x \) for \( x \in [-1,1] \), states that applying the sine function to the arcsine of \( x \) returns \( x \) itself, reflecting the fact that \( \sin^{-1} \) is the inverse function of \( \sin \) restricted to the domain \([-\pi/2, \pi/2]\). The second identity, \( \sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x \) for \( x \in [-\pi/2, \pi/2] \), indicates that the arcsine of the sine of \( x \) returns \( x \) when \( x \) lies within the principal value branch of the arcsine function. Here, \( x \) is a real variable representing either the sine value in the first identity or an angle in radians in the second. The operations involved are the sine function \( \sin \), its inverse \( \sin^{-1} \) (arcsine), and the domain restrictions ensure the functions are well-defined and invertible. This equation is central in trigonometry and analysis, underpinning the concept of inverse functions and principal branches. It ensures that the arcsine function correctly 'undoes' the sine function within the specified domains, which is crucial for solving trigonometric equations and for defining inverse trigonometric functions unambiguously. The identities relate to the broader discussion on principal values of inverse trigonometric functions, emphasizing the importance of domain restrictions to maintain function invertibility. Practically, these identities are used in calculus, geometry, and physics to solve problems involving angles and their sine values, such as in wave mechanics, signal processing, and geometric constructions. They also form the basis for more complex properties and transformations involving inverse trigonometric functions discussed in the surrounding content.

chunk-9120d0f372bdb96e0420d075b2c785c2.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { l } { \displaystyle \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( 2 x \sqrt { 1 - x ^ { 2 } } \right) = 2 \sin ^ { - 1 } x , - \frac { 1 } { \sqrt { 2 } } \leq x \leq \frac { 1 } { \sqrt { 2 } } } \\ { \displaystyle \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( 2 x \sqrt { 1 - x ^ { 2 } } \right) = 2 \cos ^ { - 1 } x , \frac { 1 } { \sqrt { 2 } } \leq x \leq 1 } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation presents a piecewise identity involving the inverse sine function (arcsin) applied to the expression 2x√(1 - x²). It states that for x in the interval [-1/√2, 1/√2], the arcsin of 2x√(1 - x²) equals twice the arcsin of x, i.e., sin⁻¹(2x√(1 - x²)) = 2 sin⁻¹(x). For x in the interval [1/√2, 1], the same expression equals twice the arccosine of x, i.e., sin⁻¹(2x√(1 - x²)) = 2 cos⁻¹(x). Here, x is a real variable constrained within the domain of the inverse trigonometric functions to ensure the expressions are well-defined. The function 2x√(1 - x²) is recognized as the sine of double an angle when x = sin θ or cos θ, reflecting the double-angle identity sin(2θ) = 2 sin θ cos θ. The equation leverages the principal value branches of inverse sine and cosine functions, ensuring the outputs lie within their standard ranges. This identity is significant in trigonometry as it connects inverse sine and cosine functions through double-angle transformations, facilitating simplification and evaluation of expressions involving inverse trigonometric functions. It also exemplifies the domain-dependent nature of inverse trigonometric identities, highlighting the necessity to consider domain restrictions for validity. The equation relates to the broader discussion on properties and simplifications of inverse trigonometric functions, serving as a foundational example in the study of their behavior and interrelations. Practical applications include solving trigonometric equations, integration involving inverse trigonometric functions, and problems in physics and engineering where angle transformations are essential.
chunk-9120d0f372bdb96e0420d075b2c785c2.modal_entity_name: Double-Angle Identity for Inverse Sine Function (equation)

chunk-ac11fca5df845f1f410cfb0eaa166516.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } & { \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( 2 x \sqrt { 1 - x ^ { 2 } } \right) = \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( 2 \sin \theta \sqrt { 1 - \sin ^ { 2 } \theta } \right) } \\ & { \phantom { \frac { 1 } { 1 } } = \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta \right) = \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( \sin 2 \theta \right) = 2 \theta } \\ & { \phantom { \frac { 1 } { 1 } } = 2 \sin ^ { - 1 } x } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation demonstrates a fundamental identity involving inverse sine functions and trigonometric double-angle formulas. It starts with the expression \( \sin^{-1} \left( 2x \sqrt{1 - x^2} \right) \), where \(x = \sin \theta\). Recognizing that \( \sqrt{1 - \sin^2 \theta} = \cos \theta \), the argument inside the inverse sine becomes \( 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta \), which is the double-angle sine formula \( \sin 2\theta \). Applying the inverse sine to \( \sin 2\theta \) yields \( 2\theta \), which can be rewritten as \( 2 \sin^{-1} x \) since \( \theta = \sin^{-1} x \). The variables involved are \(x\), a real number within the domain \([-1,1]\) for the inverse sine function, and \(\theta\), an angle in radians such that \(x = \sin \theta\). The operations include inverse trigonometric functions (\(\sin^{-1}\)), square roots, and the use of trigonometric identities, specifically the double-angle formula for sine. This identity is significant in simplifying expressions involving inverse trigonometric functions and is foundational in calculus, signal processing, and geometry. It relates inverse sine of a composite argument to a linear multiple of the inverse sine of the original variable, illustrating the interplay between algebraic manipulation and trigonometric identities. The equation fits within the broader discussion of properties and simplifications of inverse trigonometric functions, emphasizing principal value branches and domain considerations. Practically, it aids in integration, solving trigonometric equations, and transforming expressions in physics and engineering contexts where angles and their sines are involved.

chunk-5cf401d17f36cf5b36fac7b3a0d4fd1d.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\tan ^ { - 1 } \left( { \frac { \cos x } { 1 - \sin x } } \right) = \tan ^ { - 1 } \left[ { \frac { \cos ^ { 2 } { \frac { x } { 2 } } - \sin ^ { 2 } { \frac { x } { 2 } } } { \cos ^ { 2 } { \frac { x } { 2 } } + \sin ^ { 2 } { \frac { x } { 2 } } - 2 \sin { \frac { x } { 2 } } \cos { \frac { x } { 2 } } } } \right]
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation expresses the inverse tangent (arctan) of a trigonometric ratio involving sine and cosine functions of an angle x. The left-hand side is \( \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{\cos x}{1 - \sin x} \right) \), which is a common form encountered in trigonometric simplifications and inverse function evaluations. The right-hand side rewrites the argument inside the arctan function using half-angle identities: \( \cos x = \cos^2 \frac{x}{2} - \sin^2 \frac{x}{2} \) and \( \sin x = 2 \sin \frac{x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2} \). The denominator is expanded as \( 1 - \sin x = \cos^2 \frac{x}{2} + \sin^2 \frac{x}{2} - 2 \sin \frac{x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2} \), which simplifies to \( (\cos \frac{x}{2} - \sin \frac{x}{2})^2 \). This transformation leverages Pythagorean and double-angle identities to rewrite the original expression in terms of half-angle functions, facilitating simplification or evaluation. Variables: \( x \) is a real variable representing an angle, typically in radians, within the domain where the inverse tangent and trigonometric functions are defined. Mathematical operations include inverse trigonometric functions (arctan), trigonometric functions (sine and cosine), algebraic fractions, and the use of trigonometric identities (double-angle and Pythagorean identities). The application domain is trigonometry, specifically the study of inverse trigonometric functions and their properties, as well as simplification techniques. The equation is significant in demonstrating how complex trigonometric expressions can be rewritten using half-angle formulas, which is useful in integration, solving equations, and analyzing periodic phenomena. It relates to the broader discussion on properties and simplifications of inverse trigonometric functions, as seen in the surrounding context where inverse sine, cosine, and tangent functions and their principal values are explored. Practical applications include solving trigonometric equations, signal processing, physics problems involving oscillations, and anywhere inverse trigonometric functions arise. This equation exemplifies the method of expressing inverse trigonometric functions in simpler or alternative forms to facilitate computation or theoretical analysis within the framework of inverse trigonometric function properties.

chunk-68853e36a9320861fd65bb6787b3d15a.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
= \tan ^ { - 1 } \left[ { \frac { \displaystyle ( \cos { \frac { x } { 2 } } + \sin { \frac { x } { 2 } } ) \Big ( \cos { \frac { x } { 2 } } - \sin { \frac { x } { 2 } } \Big ) } { \displaystyle \left( \cos { \frac { x } { 2 } } - \sin { \frac { x } { 2 } } \right) ^ { 2 } } } \right]
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation expresses an inverse tangent function, specifically \( \tan^{-1} \), applied to a rational expression involving trigonometric functions of half-angles. The numerator is the product of \( \cos \frac{x}{2} + \sin \frac{x}{2} \) and \( \cos \frac{x}{2} - \sin \frac{x}{2} \), while the denominator is the square of \( \cos \frac{x}{2} - \sin \frac{x}{2} \). Simplifying the numerator using the difference of squares identity yields \( \cos^2 \frac{x}{2} - \sin^2 \frac{x}{2} = \cos x \). The denominator expands to \( (\cos \frac{x}{2} - \sin \frac{x}{2})^2 = \cos^2 \frac{x}{2} - 2 \sin \frac{x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2} + \sin^2 \frac{x}{2} = 1 - \sin x \) by using Pythagorean identities and double-angle formulas. Thus, the argument of the inverse tangent simplifies to \( \frac{\cos x}{1 - \sin x} \). This expression is a classic form encountered in inverse trigonometric function identities and simplifications. The variable \( x \) is a real number within the domain where the involved trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions are defined, typically \( x \in (-\pi, \pi) \) or a subset thereof to ensure principal values. The equation is situated in the context of exploring properties and simplifications of inverse trigonometric functions, particularly focusing on expressing complex inverse trigonometric expressions in simpler or more recognizable forms. The mathematical operations include trigonometric addition and subtraction, squaring, and the application of inverse tangent, which is the inverse function of the tangent function restricted to its principal branch. The theoretical significance lies in demonstrating how compound trigonometric expressions can be reduced to simpler forms, facilitating easier evaluation and understanding of inverse trigonometric functions. This relates to the broader discussion on the properties and identities of inverse trigonometric functions, their principal values, and domain considerations. Practical applications include solving integrals, evaluating limits, and simplifying expressions in calculus, physics, and engineering problems where inverse trigonometric functions arise naturally. The equation exemplifies the use of half-angle formulas and algebraic manipulation to transform and simplify inverse trigonometric expressions within the framework of the textbook's focus on inverse trigonometric function properties and exercises.

chunk-0ec6f18fddca8e5b95726ea975118186.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
= \tan ^ { - 1 } \left[ { \frac { \cos { \frac { x } { 2 } } + \sin { \frac { x } { 2 } } } { \cos { \frac { x } { 2 } } - \sin { \frac { x } { 2 } } } } \right] = \tan ^ { - 1 } \left[ { \frac { 1 + \tan { \frac { x } { 2 } } } { 1 - \tan { \frac { x } { 2 } } } } \right]
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation expresses an inverse tangent function of a rational expression involving trigonometric functions of half an angle, specifically cosine and sine of x/2. The left-hand side is \( \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{\cos \frac{x}{2} + \sin \frac{x}{2}}{\cos \frac{x}{2} - \sin \frac{x}{2}} \right) \), which is then rewritten using the tangent half-angle identity as \( \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{1 + \tan \frac{x}{2}}{1 - \tan \frac{x}{2}} \right) \). Here, \(x\) is a real variable typically representing an angle measured in radians. The equation leverages the tangent addition formula, where \( \frac{1 + t}{1 - t} = \tan \left( \frac{\pi}{4} + \theta \right) \) if \( t = \tan \theta \), indicating a transformation of the argument inside the inverse tangent function. The mathematical operations include inverse trigonometric functions (arctangent), basic trigonometric functions (sine, cosine, tangent), and algebraic manipulation of fractions. This identity is significant in simplifying expressions involving inverse trigonometric functions, particularly in integration, solving trigonometric equations, and analyzing angles in geometry or physics. It relates closely to the half-angle formulas and the addition formulas for tangent, which are fundamental in trigonometry. In the broader context of the surrounding content, which discusses properties and simplifications of inverse trigonometric functions, this equation exemplifies how complex inverse trigonometric expressions can be transformed into simpler or more recognizable forms, aiding in problem-solving and theoretical proofs. Practical applications include signal processing, wave analysis, and any domain requiring angle transformations or simplifications of trigonometric expressions.

chunk-2e150fc3d66b186fe2cc1968016385bc.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
= \tan ^ { - 1 } \left[ \tan \left( { \frac { \pi } { 4 } } + { \frac { x } { 2 } } \right) \right] = { \frac { \pi } { 4 } } + { \frac { x } { 2 } }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation expresses the inverse tangent (arctan) of the tangent of a sum of angles, specifically \( \tan^{-1} \left[ \tan \left( \frac{\pi}{4} + \frac{x}{2} \right) \right] = \frac{\pi}{4} + \frac{x}{2} \). Mathematically, it leverages the property that the arctan function is the inverse of the tan function within its principal value branch, which is \( \left(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \). The variable \(x\) is a real number constrained such that the argument \( \frac{\pi}{4} + \frac{x}{2} \) lies within the principal branch of the tangent function to ensure the equality holds without ambiguity. The operations involved include the tangent function, its inverse (arctan), and addition and division of real numbers. This equation is situated in the context of inverse trigonometric function properties, particularly demonstrating the simplification of compositions of trig and inverse trig functions. It highlights the importance of domain restrictions for inverse functions to maintain one-to-one correspondence. Theoretically, it confirms that for angles within the principal range, the arctan of tan of an angle returns the angle itself. Practically, such identities are crucial in calculus, signal processing, and geometry for simplifying expressions and solving equations involving inverse trigonometric functions. This equation exemplifies the broader framework of understanding principal branches and domain considerations in inverse trigonometric functions, which is essential for correctly applying these functions in mathematical analysis and problem-solving.

chunk-14122266c914e7dbed858474cbfbddf8.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } { { 1 . } } & { { 3 \sin ^ { - 1 } x = \sin ^ { - 1 } ( 3 x - 4 x ^ { 3 } ) , ~ x \in \left[ - \displaystyle \frac { 1 } { 2 } , \displaystyle \frac { 1 } { 2 } \right] \hfill } } \\ { { 2 . } } & { { 3 \cos ^ { - 1 } x = \cos ^ { - 1 } ( 4 x ^ { 3 } - 3 x ) , ~ x \in \left[ \displaystyle \frac { 1 } { 2 } , \displaystyle 1 \right] \hfill } } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equations express triple-angle identities for inverse sine and inverse cosine functions. Specifically, the first equation states that for x in the interval [-1/2, 1/2], three times the arcsine of x equals the arcsine of the cubic polynomial 3x - 4x^3. This polynomial corresponds to the sine of triple an angle, i.e., sin(3θ) = 3sinθ - 4sin^3θ, where θ = sin^(-1)(x). Similarly, the second equation states that for x in [1/2, 1], three times the arccosine of x equals the arccosine of 4x^3 - 3x, which corresponds to the cosine triple-angle identity cos(3θ) = 4cos^3θ - 3cosθ, with θ = cos^(-1)(x). The variables x represent the sine or cosine of an angle θ within specified domains ensuring the principal values of inverse trigonometric functions. The operations involve inverse trigonometric functions (arcsin, arccos), polynomial expressions, and the concept of function composition. These identities are fundamental in trigonometry, enabling simplification of expressions involving multiple angles and inverse functions. They also illustrate the interplay between polynomial expressions and trigonometric functions, highlighting the algebraic structure underlying trigonometric identities. In the broader context of the surrounding material, which discusses simplification of inverse trigonometric expressions and principal value branches, these equations serve as canonical examples demonstrating how inverse functions of multiple angles can be expressed in terms of single-angle inverse functions. Practical applications include solving trigonometric equations, signal processing, and any domain requiring angle transformations or simplifications. The equations reinforce the theoretical framework of inverse trigonometric function properties and their manipulation within defined domains to maintain function invertibility and principal value consistency.

chunk-ebbb4fc16492b21f9c8231e34fa7976c.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
{ \begin{array} { r l } { . } & { \tan ^ { - 1 } \left[ 2 \cos \left( 2 \sin ^ { - 1 } { \frac { 1 } { 2 } } \right) \right] } \\ { . } & { \tan { \frac { 1 } { 2 } } \left[ \sin ^ { - 1 } { \frac { 2 x } { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } } + \cos ^ { - 1 } { \frac { 1 - y ^ { 2 } } { 1 + y ^ { 2 } } } \right] , | x | < 1 , y > 0 { \mathrm { ~ a n d ~ } } x y < 1 } \end{array} }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: This equation involves inverse trigonometric functions, specifically the arctangent (tan^{-1}), arcsine (sin^{-1}), and arccosine (cos^{-1}) functions, combined with trigonometric expressions. The first part, \( \tan^{-1} \left[ 2 \cos \left( 2 \sin^{-1} \frac{1}{2} \right) \right] \), evaluates the arctangent of twice the cosine of twice the arcsine of 1/2. Since \( \sin^{-1} \frac{1}{2} = \frac{\pi}{6} \), this simplifies to \( \tan^{-1} [ 2 \cos ( \frac{\pi}{3} ) ] = \tan^{-1} (2 \times \frac{1}{2}) = \tan^{-1} (1) = \frac{\pi}{4} \). The second part, \( \tan \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin^{-1} \frac{2x}{1+x^2} + \cos^{-1} \frac{1 - y^2}{1 + y^2} \right] \), involves the tangent of half an angle multiplied by the sum of arcsine and arccosine expressions with rational functions of variables \(x\) and \(y\). The conditions \( |x| < 1, y > 0, \text{and } xy < 1 \) ensure the arguments lie within the domains of the inverse trigonometric functions. The expressions \( \frac{2x}{1+x^2} \) and \( \frac{1 - y^2}{1 + y^2} \) are well-known parametrizations related to the sine and cosine of double angles via the tangent half-angle substitution. This equation exemplifies the use of inverse trigonometric identities and transformations to simplify complex expressions, a common theme in the surrounding context which focuses on rewriting inverse trigonometric functions in simpler or alternative forms. The equation is significant in demonstrating the interplay between inverse functions and trigonometric identities, highlighting the principal value branches and domain restrictions. It relates to the broader discussion on simplifying inverse trigonometric expressions, proving identities, and evaluating expressions within specified domains. Practical applications include solving integrals, trigonometric equation solving, and geometric interpretations in fields such as signal processing, physics, and engineering where angle transformations are essential.

chunk-4c8cc85ab7e945939890a3c2adee526c.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\scriptstyle { \begin{array} { l } { \sin ^ { - 1 } \left( \sin { \frac { 2 \pi } { 3 } } \right) } \\ { \tan \left( \sin ^ { - 1 } { \frac { 3 } { 5 } } + \cot ^ { - 1 } { \frac { 3 } { 2 } } \right) } \end{array} }
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given expressions involve inverse trigonometric functions and their compositions with trigonometric functions, illustrating key properties of principal values and angle addition formulas. The first expression, \( \sin^{-1}(\sin \frac{2\pi}{3}) \), highlights the principal value branch of the arcsine function, which restricts outputs to \( [-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}] \). Since \( \frac{2\pi}{3} \) lies outside this interval, the expression simplifies to \( \sin^{-1}(\sin \frac{2\pi}{3}) = \frac{\pi}{3} \), reflecting the periodicity and symmetry of sine. The second expression, \( \tan \left( \sin^{-1} \frac{3}{5} + \cot^{-1} \frac{3}{2} \right) \), uses the angle addition formula for tangent: \( \tan(A+B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B} \). Here, \( A = \sin^{-1} \frac{3}{5} \) and \( B = \cot^{-1} \frac{3}{2} \). By interpreting \( \sin^{-1} \frac{3}{5} \) as an angle with sine \( \frac{3}{5} \) and \( \cot^{-1} \frac{3}{2} \) as an angle with cotangent \( \frac{3}{2} \), one can find their tangents and compute the sum's tangent. This demonstrates the interplay between inverse trigonometric functions and their corresponding direct functions, emphasizing transformations between different trigonometric ratios. The variables represent angles or ratios derived from geometric or analytic contexts, with domain restrictions ensuring function validity. These expressions are fundamental in calculus, geometry, and engineering, where angle transformations and inverse functions are crucial. They relate to the broader discussion on simplifying inverse trigonometric expressions, understanding principal branches, and applying trigonometric identities to solve equations or evaluate expressions in a principal value context.

chunk-c47249092e424fab699b47ad010b236b.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\cos ^ { - 1 } \left( \cos { \frac { 1 3 \pi } { 6 } } \right)
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation \( \cos^{-1} \left( \cos \frac{13\pi}{6} \right) \) represents the principal value of the inverse cosine function applied to the cosine of an angle \( \frac{13\pi}{6} \). Mathematically, \( \cos^{-1}(\cos x) \) returns the unique angle \( y \) in the principal range \( [0, \pi] \) such that \( \cos y = \cos x \). Here, the variable \( x = \frac{13\pi}{6} \) is an angle measured in radians, exceeding the principal range of the inverse cosine function. The operation involves the composition of the cosine function and its inverse, which is not an identity for all real numbers due to the restricted range of \( \cos^{-1} \). The principal value branch of \( \cos^{-1} \) restricts outputs to \( [0, \pi] \), so the expression simplifies by finding an equivalent angle within this interval that shares the same cosine value as \( \frac{13\pi}{6} \). Since \( \frac{13\pi}{6} = 2\pi + \frac{\pi}{6} \), and cosine is periodic with period \( 2\pi \), \( \cos \frac{13\pi}{6} = \cos \frac{\pi}{6} \). Because \( \frac{\pi}{6} \in [0, \pi] \), the principal value is \( \frac{\pi}{6} \). This equation exemplifies the concept of principal branches of inverse trigonometric functions and their role in ensuring single-valued outputs. It is fundamental in trigonometry, calculus, and complex analysis, especially when dealing with angle normalization, solving trigonometric equations, and defining inverse functions on restricted domains. The equation relates to other examples in the context that illustrate the behavior of inverse trigonometric functions when their arguments lie outside the principal domain, emphasizing the importance of understanding periodicity and principal value branches. Practical applications include signal processing, physics (wave analysis), and engineering where angle measurements must be normalized within principal intervals for consistent interpretation.

chunk-c85319569fc34a9f70f0ff4f736456a4.content:
